title: Is it natural to say this to a little child, 'keep your both feet parallel to each other'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Very few children will know the word “parallel “. They probably haven’t learned the concept of “both”, either. Keep it simple: “Keep your feet together!” Show them how to do it, or show them a picture. You could teach the word “feet”, and the two words “together” and “apart”. Then you could have a little game where you say “feet apart!” Or “feet together!” And they do it. Two teams, whoever does the correct action first gets a point. Then you do it, and they say “feet together “ or “feet apart” (hearing and identifying is easier than producing the words, so you should order activities like this). This could be a game with the same rules as above.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hung Ha Manh

response.answer_text: I’m not sure about American kids, but my mom used to say something like that in Russian to a toddler she babysat. In my opinion, it’s perfectly natural and a good way for a child to learn math and to lie still at the same time. Some kids can be super fidgety so it’s hard for them to sleep quickly.
